Built in 15th century CE, the Nallur Kovil in Jaffna is sacred to the Hindu believers of Sri Lanka. Incidentally, it was built by the adopted son of a Sinhala King, Parakramabahu VI of the Kotte Kingdom, who built it for the benefit of the Hindu populace of Jaffna after defeating the invading forces of the Vijayanagar Empire of South India. The original Nallur Kovil was razed to the ground by the Portuguese and later rebuilt in an adjacent location by the Dutch in 1734. The Nallur Kovil, set amidst the scorched terrain of the North, still has a sacredness that is radiated in the front courtyard, the Dravidian architecture and the majestic and ornately carved gopuram or tower at the entrance. There are many festivals at Nallur Kovil that attract Hindu devotees from around the world, in addition to the many spectators who take pleasure in the pomp and pageantry of the celebrations.

Nallur temple is huge and the compound in front is huge too to accommodate many devotees.  The golden coloured five storeyed gopuram or the tower, in Dravidian architectural style, is decorated and carved with many figures of Hindu gods. Murugan or Skanda (Kataragama god) is the sacred deity of this temple with other deities Ganesh, Vairavar, and others surrounding him in the inner yard.  Offerings are conducted many times a day within the temple by devotees who come here in thousands. Visitors are required to behave with decorum as this is a temple. We removed our shoes before entering the premises handing them over to a caretaker. Males entering the temple remove their shirts. Inside the temple are figures of various gods and many murals depicting incidents, beliefs and stories related to Hindu mythology. I was disappointed that no photography was permitted within the temple.  Authorities, when asked told me that this is to prevent reproduction of the murals for commercial purposes.

Nallur Kandaswamy Temple lies about 3km from the Jaffna town on the KKS (Kankasanthurai) Road. This is one of the most important temples in the Jaffna Peninsula and the most well known. The history of the temple dates back to the time of King Parakramabahu VI (1411-1463) of Kotte Kingdom . King Parakramabahu VI had two adopted sons, Sapumal Kumaraya (prince) and Ambulugala Kumaraya (prince). The king sent prince Sapumal to the north where the South Indian Vijayanagar Empire was trying to attach Jaffna. The prince successfully drove away the invaders killing the king Arya Chakravarthi, and brought his wife and children to Kotte . The King Parakramabahu VI appointed the Prince Sapumal as the regional ruler of Jaffna. It was this prince who built the Nallur Kovil for the hindu people of Jaffna. Prince Sapumal later had to leave Jaffna to take over the Kingship of the whole island at Kotte . He was consecrated as King Buwanekabahu VI of Kotte .

This temple is unique in that it houses a VEL ( Spear) the main weapon carried by the Hindu God Lord Murugan (also worshipped with other names as Kandaswamy, Shanmugha etc.) in the Sanctum Sanctorum instead of his idol. This symbolises Lord Murugan‚Äôs assured protection to those who worship and pray to grant their wishes and seek his protection. The temple has majestic Gopuram ( decorative tower) facing east, south and north. Whilst the east gopuram has five storeys in its elevation, the south and north have seven storeys. Each storey is adorned with god‚Äôs sculptures , typical of any hindu temple. The east gopuram is especially beautiful as it also houses a decorative arch. As is common with all hindu temples there is a small pond near the south gopuram. The interior of the temple carries excellent wall paintings depicting stories , decorated wooden structures and  small grotos for Lord Ganesha, Lord Murugan‚Äôs consorts Valli and Devayanai, infant Krishna, Sun and the Trident. The main annual festival is held for 27 days beginning on the New moon day in the tamil month of Aadi and lasts till the new moon day in the month of Avani ( typically the entire month of August).This is a major attraction of Jaffna not to be missed and visitors come here specially to pray at the temple. Vistors should take note of temple opening times and prayer timings.

The Hindu Temple Nallur Kandaswamy temple is situated in the not so tourist area of Jaffna. Visitors before entering the Temple complex must remove their shoes; men need to remove their shirts as well. The Temple is about 1.5km northeast of the centre. It is exceptionally beautifully colourful, as one would expect from a Hindu Temple dedicated to sacred deity is Lord Murugan (or Skanda). One thing that struck me was the friendliness of the devotees and visitors entering the Temple complex.  Even though we could not speak Tamil or Sinhalese the people actually pushed us into places where we could view the ceremony of the "Puja" and then took us by hand to the following 3 or 4 places so as we could be and feel integrated into the ceremonial process. In western religions it's normally first come first served and you're pushed out of the way by the surge of petitions and penitents trying to gain a favour or miracle from the devotion.  But here the people were so keen for us to see the adoration of their gods and the ceremony unfold that we were at times led by the hand to "the next installment" - for want of a better phrase. Then once the ceremony had finished we wandered around the Temple complex and some visitors - from the southern part of India,  took us to one side and helped us understand what we had just witnessed Several friendly priests, some of whom speak English, can answer questions about the temple and its traditions. Do go to this and any Temple that you find near you on your visits and be inspired and blessed as we were that day at The Nallur Kandaswamy Temple.

We spent two days in around  Jaffna town. The Nallur Kovil ( Hindu temple) is in the center of town and easily the main attraction.  Recently restored and  repainted with a magnificent central shrine and several smaller shrines in the perimeter of the main shrine. try to coordinate visit with a time of "pooja" ceremony ( several times per day morning and evenings) when the priests offer prayers and offerings on behalf of the devotees gathered. This is done to the accompaniment of traditional music ( drums and long flute ) providing atmosphere and charm. After the pooja ceremony take time to walk around the inner perimeter of the main temple, with long corridors in classical style to take in the several large murals and carved stone statues depicting other gods and goddesses exquisitely done in gold and vivid colors.  Also take note of the 20 foot carved wooden doors at each of the entrances and the "gopurams" towers that painted in gold.  Striking are the two newer gopurams on the north and south completed recently.  to enter the temple you must go barefooted and males must be bare waist up. No photography. Outside and in the surrounding streets outside this temple are several smaller "kovils"  that also prvide interesting viewing and early morning "poojas".  Well worth a visit to this vicinity...  devote about 1-2 hours

visited the Nallur Kovil during our recent visit to Jaffna. Participated in a Pooja. Men have to take their shirts off. Sampled the mouth watering RIO ice cream which is in close proximity to the temple.
Its really nice place to go in the evenings specially in friday evenings. You can visit to the rio ice cream and one of the oldest kings place also near by jaffna temple.
One of the most interesting Hindu temples in the North. A must when in Jaffna. Be sure to visit during puja hours.

Surprisingly large area. Be prepared to remove your shirt if you are male. I was disappointed that I was unable to take photos inside. I suggest you leave your shoes in your vehicle or by the outer fence. Mine were moved from where I left them near the main building - I thought that they had been stolen.
Very clear secluded sacred area - well maintained. Very Punctual Prayer functions - quite likable. Festive seasons are a real Gift to watch and enjoy and get spiritual enlightenment

Beautiful, historical temple full of spiritual significance for Jaffna and the north. Well worth a visit. I would avoid the pooja times as it can be very crowded. Note that men need to take off their shirts when entering the temple. Women are not allowed to enter in shorts or very short skirts.

The temple is Ok, but nothing if you compare with tamil temples in Tamil Nadu, since this Nallur is quiet modern as a building. But it is the main attraction in Jaffna and pujas are performed often in the evening. Priests are friendly and helpful with the tourists
It was a great opportunity to visit this world famous temple, a lovely place full of history. A must visit if one visits Jaffna. Be appropriately dressed as a mark of respect to Hinduism.

This is one of the huge temple in Jaffna .The festivals begins on ist August and goes for nearly 3 weeks.Devotees come from different parts of SriLanka and worship the lord Murugan. At Night  you can  see colorful beautiful lights. This is situated  on the way To Point Pedro Road.People take buses from Jaffna Bus stand and who are residing  walk to the temple.During the festival time it is packed with crowds and mini shops,Ice Cream,rubber product,Bangles vendors..It will be an exciting evening.
Its a religious site and recommend to any type of travellers....men cannot enter with shirts or tshirts...wonderful architectural site too....

It is a majestic looking building. If you are a Hindu or interested in religions it is worth going inside. There are  seasonal festivals with beating of drums and rituals. The calendar could be obtained from the hotel or locals.

We wanted to visit the temple during a pooja but we coudn't do it. If you are planning to visit the temple make sure that men has to take of their shirts before going to the temple. It is a place you must see.
If you go Jaffna you must visit Nallur Kovil definitely. This is a very ancient kovil and very charming Place.

I went with my spouse and children. This was. Strip down memory lane for me - I have been at this kovil many times as a child with my own parents. It is a restive place for self- reflection, meditation, being at peace.  I would highly recommend a visit - well worth it.

Many of the tourist maps of Sri Lanka would not point out anything in the Northern Sri Lanka (I wonder why) but this temple is worth visiting because it is not a major tourist attraction but it is more local people who visit here. The best part is going during festivities called a 'Thiruvila' Be sure to talk to  a local person, English is one of Sri Lanka's main foreign language or even better greet someone saying 'vanakam' (Tamil for welcome/hello)

we visit at evening time. it was quite place. we couldn't enter inside of the temple, because the entrance door was shut. i didn't event get the pooja times. But we spent lots of time on the temple surrounding. Rio Ice cream is on the surrounding. It is really nice

Locates in the city premises of Jaffna and full of devotees. People who newly started their businesses, visit the kovil in large numbers. The vel festival season starts Augest attracts thousands of devotees from all around the world. Photography, is prohibited in side the Kovil. One priest always stand by the entrance of the shrine make sure your devices are switched off. Scrolling on hot sand, breaking chanted coconuts on a holly rock and offering fresh fruit baskets are the main events to destroy evil eyes and evil mouth in the favour of God SKANDHA.....

The 'Kovil' is crowded throughout the day with devotees from all walks of life thronging for blessings.  This has been a land mark of Jaffna for a very long time.  Worth a visit for visitors to Jaffna.
Well kept and definitely a place to visit if in Jaffna. Parking is done right out side the Kovil, so has easy access. Must Visit!
Well known and must visited place in Jaffna - local people visits regularly for pryers and now another good attraction for tourist. The temple is constructed artistically. Must visit
looks really pretty and majestic almost from any which way you look at it. located in the central part of the town it's hard to miss.

Beautiful Hindu Tempel and great Architecture. If you're in Jaffna, a must see Tempel. Unfortunately no photos are allowed inside the tempel. But it was one of the coolest tempel in whole Sri Lanka, therefore no regrets.
Historical place - do visit when you are at Jaffna, been their to see the architecture of this temple.
A large beautiful temple with monumental brightly-painted ornate towers. But I am not sure why they are building another tower. The money could be spent on other charitable social programmes.
One of the major sights in Jaffna, so probably worth seeing. Just dont plan to spend too much time on it - after all, it is quite boring.

It is a nice and big temple. It was not destroyed during the fight. Thanks to the God for saving himself

Nallur Kovil is one of the most famous Hindu Kovils in the island. This is not a touristy place, its a religious one. Go only if you wish to soak in the authentic atmosphere of devotees coming to make their offerings and obtain blessings. Take of hats and shoes before entering, males are also required to remove their shirts before entering. Not exactly a calm place when the religious service is taking place its nevertheless a good opportunity to observe local rituals up close.
This is an interesting Kovil to visit. I found the colours to be different from the rest. Guys! You need to take your shirt off when entering :-)

A temple with a lot of history and great structure of gods and goddesses. Going during the prayer times would be interesting with crowds walking from one god to another with priests chanting and performing different rituals.

Yes indeed, this is for connoisseurs....to see the God of Kataragama, (Murugan)  lifted from his place in the main concourse and placed gently on a little cart which is pulled  by two men stripped to the waist round the temple while a brahmin priest wafts a whisk to keep the flies and other desecrations off the God and then He is placed reverently between his two Wives in a side chapel so He can spend the night with Them...and the gold of the gopuram in the early morning or early evening light of a low lying sun!!

Temple is still being renovated but you can  still marvel at its architectural beauty & lovely murals.  You may be lucky to see one of the several puja ceremonies.  Unfortunately, no picture-taking inside.

I have visited some Hindu temples in sri lanka, but this is the biggest temple I have visited by far, we went during the festival season and it was over crowded,but  still you can go inside, (gents have to go topless) the art work inside the temple is also impressive

To get there is quite a challenge. It is not the colourful Hindu temple you might expect. The inside of the temple is bare of any decorations. Outside the temple, the nice sculptures the Hindu temples are so famous for, are painted in one colour.
This temple is open early 4:30 AM and closes 5:45 PM.  plan accordingly. Easily accessible, and a must see in Jaffna. The temple has a huge building. Men are expected to enter in without shirts.

If you visited Hindu temples in South India like Madurai Meenatchi Amman, Srirangam, Thanjavur Kovil, this temple not impressive. But in SriLanka this temple one of the beautiful and most respected by the Hindus. Still they maintain the old culture here - to enter the Kovil all males want to remove their shirts etc-. Pooja time bit of crowded. Kovil is so called ancient, but can't see any signs! Other big menace is the beggars. Really a temple like this can make some jobs for them and keep them occupied. If the management of the temple start with some plans, every devotees will be donate. Evening time sit on the sand in front of the temple and eating some roasted peanuts is relaxing experience!

This is one of the ancient lord muruga's temple located in Jaffna, Northern part of Sri Lanka. If you wish to do a special pooja you have to pay only Rs 1 (SLR) inside temple. There are limitations in terms of entering into this premises like without cameras, topless for men..but you are free ourside this temple. A special place to Hindus.

column7: Layer de la Haye, United Kingdom
column11: Be sure to visit while a puja is happening (5am, 10am, noon, 415pm, 430pm, 5pm and 645pm).  This is a spectacular building, both from the outside and the inside.  You'll need to remove your shoes to enter.  (take them with you or leave them at the gate).  Men need to remove their shirts to enter the temple (tuck it in your waistband at the front of your trousers).  Women need either a skirt or long trousers and long sleeves. Don't be afraid to join in, the locals will put you right straight away if you do something wrong or watch them first.   We entered and immediately were pushed along with the crowd - where women and men were separated and walking bakcwards, we walked in front of the deity as it was borne around the inside of the temple.   The deity is lit up (electric lights, as there's a small generator following it round), and there are frequent stops and offerings.   It's a magnificent spectacle - no one looks bored and everyone is engaged. The ceremony is noisy, - with drums, with wind instruments and with worshippers getting involved.  Let the noise and the experience wash over you - its like a healing ceremony, as it was explained to us.  Believers come as often as they need, to soak in the atmosphere of the ceremony and if you do come along during the ceremony you'll feel it all resonate through you. There are no photos allowed inside the temple and there were no social conversations, this was about the ceremony.

Large historical temple You are not allowed to enter wearing shirts. You have to be bare bodied to enter If you go when the religious service is on, it is crowded but you can experience exotic loud music

Go during the Pooja (Dharhan) time, I went at 4/30 p.m. and found it rewarding and tranquil. After the main Pooja one must do a complete walk around the inner corridoors of the temple and visit the other associate kovils.

I am a catholic but there is something about this place of worship it's great to see that the surroundings and the Kovil in particular are well kept and the pooja's are kept to time and schedules.A must see temple.
Superb with the front view and interior also massive and it has marvelous paintings on wall.it is great cultural value for jaffna

The Kovil is very large and there's so much to see inside, only problem was that all literature was in Tamil and we couldn't exactly understand what was there in detail. the paintings helped in some what way. its better if they have a guide book or someone who can give information in English.

Approximately 1.5km northeast of the centre, the Nallur Kandaswamy Kovil is the most impressive religious building in Jaffna and one of the most significant Hindu temple complexes in Sri Lanka. Its sacred deity is Murugan (or Skanda), and at cacophonic puja at 5am, 10am, noon, 4.15pm (small puja ), 4.30pm special puja ), 5pm and 6.45pm offerings are made to his brass-framed image and other Hindu deities like Ganesh, Murugans elephant-headed brother, in shrines surrounding the inner sanctum. You can also say a prayer at the sacred tree in the temple‚Äôs southern courtyard anytime:
The Annual Festival was on at the time we travelled to Jaffna and were able to have a  Good Dharshan of Lord Skanda. Lots of Shopping with a very contended mind.
Great temple for Murugan, an important one and very unique in it's rituals. It is known to be quite accurate on timing, so make sure to come on time for the puja (around 5:00-6:00pm evening puja).

Jaffna doesn't offer a lot of sights for tourists to see and for me this is its only real attraction. A great Hindu Temple with market streets leading to it. The Police are friendly and eager to know where you are from and are proud of there temple. Inside looks even better then the outside, but you cannot take photo's inside the temple. The locals go about praying, All men have to be shirtless, including any Police inside. The best place to visit in Jaffna
Must to visit in your Jaffna visit. There are number of sculpts of Hindu gods inside, For males removing you shirt is a must when you are entering to the kovil.
Since August is the festival season the atmosphere was great and it was lovely to see Jaffna people enjoying life just like the next person in any other part of Sri Lanka.
Fabulous colours, sounds and sights. Very serene. Shoes are safely left outside the temple. No photos inside.
The temple was beautiful build but you must wear appropriate clothing to visit no shorts or vest . A must visit in Jaffna
This is a must to all travellers. It will blow you away. The sheer size of it only unravels once inside.
Very large and colourful Hindu temple. Men have to take their shirts off to go in. Unfortunately it's not allowed to take pictures inside. Well-worth visiting.
A must visit place. Full of murals. Serene place of worship. Men take shirts off. Could be busy on a worshipping day

I really enjoyed the experience of Hindu temple rituals. I first went there just after opening A9 road after war and several times afterwords. If you are a male, you have to remove your shirt before enter in to the temple.
men will have to take off their shirts, generally to be covered in a veti sarong. Women should be in decent clothes, covered sleeves, long tops etc.
Very serene place and always people in and out. Hinduism plays a big part in Jaffna culture and this place has suevived the war ....
Very good Ancient Temple in Jaffna. Visited the Temple. the very sands at the entrance ground was a attraction. I wondered how this temple remains unafffected during the war times.

This temple stands out on approach and there is a lot of construction work taking place to make it even more impressive. Again, men have to remove shoes and shirts to enter. A service with devotees was taking place during our morning visit but there was no restriction on walking around the complex, internal and external. The terraced pool, for Hindus to cleanse themselves, is being retiled but even in its less than glamorous state is notable viewing. A negative is the number of beggars at entrance gate but buy a coconut and break it on the rock set up for this purpose as you approach church for good karma! No entry fee.
It was a quick site seeing  visit for me . My first visit to Jaffna ,Sri Lanka  . A good tourist attraction too. People dont speak english here .

We visited Nallur Kovil in the evening. There was a pooja at 5.30 and the temple closed at 06 p.m. It is very beautiful. They do not allow to take photographs inside the Kovil and men are not allowed to wear Tshirt or shirt when they enter inside the kovil.

When I saw the temple I had to say "waaaa" (I never went to India). The inside is also nice, it is huge and the architecture is very interesting. Their is a "pool" inside and the workers and religious guys are very friendly.
This is a beautiful place full of life. The chanting you hear make you feel so high. Nice carvings and drawings. Must visit place.

It's a beautiful temple and there is amazing energy. It's got amazing architecture. The temple prayers are however conducted at a certain time so be sure to check the timings before going or else you won't be able to see the deity. The ceremony is conducted in a different manner from temples in India.
It was a fantastic time in the Nallur kovil attending prayers . Arts monuments are unbelievable.  Prayer time is open only for topless men.

I went with two colleagues for the early morning pooja at 5 am. This was a colourful yet simple ceremony. The samis were very friendly. They did not charge money. A ticket was only an amazing 1rupee. The jaffna sojourn is not complete without this visit. It is a very venerated site for hindus and certain buddhists.
The nicest kovil we have seen in Sri Lanka. It is really worth visiting. The kovil is huge and well preserved. The same measures apply like in other kovils ‚Äì no shoes, no shirts for men.

we've seen lots of awesome Hindu Temples in India. Nallur Kovil is maybe an important Temple for the Tamils in Jaffna but not a true gem regarding architecture and not worth the long detour to Jaffna.

This is a Hindu religious place (Kovil). While we went there there was a religious function and we were watching it from out side. Lots of males were bear bodied. We liked the Nagasalam plying the drums and trumphets.
Didn't actually go in this time.. just spent time watching the devotees and taking photographs from the outside..

Nallur Kovil of the Jaffna...  It's situated in the city at a walking distance from most of the tourists rest houses and hotels. The Kovil is revered  for it's sacred Murugan or  Skandha diety. All people have to remove their footwear and men have to remove their shirts as well before entering the Kovil's  structure. I was there during the pooja time,  during which the music is played to please the god. The place is airy and maintained beautifully. The open ground outside the Kovil structure gives ample scope for taking pictures of the grand Kovil.

Situated on Temple Road, Nallur, just outside Jaffna Town. It is one of the most significant HIndu Kovils in the Northern Province, with its famous fstival held annually  in July -- August. It is the epitome of cleanliness, neatness and beauty and is a highly organized place of worship.The tranquility and spirituality of this temple were noteworthy. We visited during the 10 am pooja and being a non - Hindu who respects all faiths it was interesting to witness the ritual and the devotion of the faithful. A Hindu devotee in our group did the explanations so we understood the significance of the pooja. We walked right around the temple, along a beautifully decorated, highly ornate corridor . Photographs are not allowed.

We visited during the daily evening pooja. It was very interesting the music and the religious chanting mixed together.  The large temple complex offers lot of tranquility. People visit the temple without any religious differences.

Nallur kovel temple is in temple road,jaffna. You must remove your shoes before entering the temple. It is ver sacred to the hindu tamils in this area. It is large and you can walk a round but photography is forbidden.
Good place to take some lovely pictures. Be careful of all the people asking for money they can harass you.

One of the site you must see and visit. Stunning view. It s nice to be in the vicinity in an evening. Specially every body should visit during the festival period to see the rituals and culture. Nowadys it is a well marketed business point. The chariot festival is eye catching. Cultural beauty. But don't spoil it as a tourist point.

Large Hindu temple, worth a visit. We visited it at ~1545 which is the puja time. Interesting to see the local people gathering and praying. Note that men must remove the shirt (and off course the shoes) before entering the temple inside.

Very beautiful place. No photographs are allowed. You have to remove shoes and caps and should observe silence as it is a religious place.  Males have to enter without shirts. The place is very busy at times of the " Pooja".

The temple is just another hindu-temple. Even though it may be of great significance to the pious ones, it has little to offer to the visitors. The only one stunning thing about this temple is a corridor with decorated arch-like structure that offers a stunning perspective. But for anyone who might have seen temples in South India, this might be a bit of a disappointment. None the less, it has some ceremonial prayers and things like that, with trumpets and other instruments, which may be of interest. Closed after 6 pm. Photography inside the temple is not allowed. And strangely enough, men have to remove their shirts when entering the temple.

We visited the temple during the afternoon service. 1630-1730 We were welcomed into the service. We are Australian not Hindu. Although confusing, the warmth of the congregation was inclusive. The service was a mixture of drums, horns and a procession around this large and religiously important Hindu temple. I would advise trying to visit during this or the morning prayers (not sure of the time of he morning service) In fact I don't think it is open out of these two service periods, so check with a local

I visited this temple as a tourist and not a devotee but was treated extremely rudely by the local Tamil people. You would think think that a place of worship such as this kind and considerate behaviour would be the norm but it is unforuntately the exception! If visiting I would suggest go at times when the locals aren't thronging it and behaving in an unruly manner. The temple itself is quite nice to see with however and a nice insight into the religious life of the local people. All said and done, give Jaffna a miss until the people there open up a bit more and the population catches up with moderan civilisation, including the idea of being polite, friendly and welcoming to foreigners!

Honestly, there is no point in going out of one's way to visit this temple. It may have some sentimental value to Tamil Hindus, but for non-Hindus it has nothing much to offer; you will see the same thing if you went to a Hindu temple in Colombo or anywhere else in the country. The only thing here is that males have to remove their shirts to enter, which is a silly rule to impose given that it is not followed elsewhere. The red and white stripes everywhere on the walls reminded me of candy cane. If you want a more psychedelic temple visit the one on Nainativu island which is painted in every colour imaginable.

Suggest that they keep it open a little longer ; we went there on two days but both days it was closed ; it was a Friday & Saturday ; Fiday was a public holiday ; perhaps they close on public holidays. But from out side its a beautiful kovil.

If your a Hindu devotee or just a tourist try to visit this place. Gives and insight in to a totally different culture. Women must dress appropriately, men must be shirtless and no photography allowed inside. Temple is only opened during certain times so check up before you visit. If you are not interested in the Pooja then try to avoid the peak season. Do visit if your in need for peace of mind!!! Making a donation is advised!!

Having been almost templed out, the general experience of Hindu temples is one of visual senses being overwhelmed.  No disrespect at all intended.  This temple is grand in it's openness, the front doors are exquisite, hundreds of brass door knobs, and the pool in the courtyard is serene.   What was quite concerning was the men having to take off their shirts.....makes we Aussies stand out a bit more than usual.     As I said this temple was beautiful, but not overwhelming.

It was the first time i went Jaffna and it was an amazing experience. One trip that blew my mind. Apperantly we were lodging in a place near the Nallur temple which i didnt know first. Being a non hindu i thought this is a noicy and humongous place crowded with people. A person told the kovil is walking distance from the place we stayd. So one day early morning we went to have a look.... It was amazing site. The temple was specious and wasnt croded at all. Maybe because its not the festive seson. Men have to go inside only after removing the shirt to show there respect. And like in all other temples in Sri Lanka removing footwear is a must. And one should dress decent thats also like in other temples. When i was roming around the temple I saw some people gathering around near a door way of a hall of a shrine. I also walked there to see whats going on. It was a beautiful pooja that my eyes were lucky to witness. The whole room was glowing with lights in golden colour and bells were ringing with chants. Everybody were with high spirits. It was a moment everybody were blissfully happy.

I went to this temple after 12 years, lot of changes some are new. This is an ancient and powerfull temple. Unfortunately the ancient appearence is not there look more modern. All can go into the temple as usual practice in the hindu temples you have to leave your footwear out, further Gents cannot wear shirt or tee shirts you allowed bare body, ladies should wear decent dress no short skirts or shorts. The temple has very strict rules to follow but nothing hard for us. No photos inside but you can take photos outside. Some staffs are fluent in English they are little helpfull There is no fee  for entrance. If you are a hind and if you go to Jaffna you must visit this temple, it is like vatican in Rome
The most popular Hindu temple in Jaffna. Very majestic. People come from all over Sri Lanka and overseas to worship at this temple dedicated to Lord Murugan.

This old Kovil is beautiful in its architecture, and serenity. It did seem a bit quiet when we visited, and didn't have the atmsphere you would expect in a grand Kovil, but it a beautiful space to walk around. I didn't appreciate the frills and chandelliers that were present. However, I do agree there are some more charismatic kovils around the country, but we have to remember that until 4 years ago, Jaffna was in the centre of a civil war, with much delapidation and destruction in the city, which is slowly but surely trying to piece itself together. I am sorry that the other travellers have had such negative experiences. All I can say is give it a few more years and please visit again.

This temple pales in comparison to the great Hindu temples of South India. It is a poor imitation, bereft of the grandeur, majesty and spirituality of its cousins in India. The local Tamil people are also quite unfriendly (a consequence of the long war perhaps?), without the usual smiles common in the rest of Sri Lanka. The temple seems like a tourist trap. Unfortunately, cannot recommend visiting until the experience changes.

This is supposed to be a very old temple but there is nothing ancient to be seen. Every construction is modern, with cement and bright gaudy colours that do no justice to the history of the temple. Men have to remove their shirts in order to enter which detracts from the spirituality of the area and is not a pleasant experience when it gets busy during the pooja times. The temple priests seem to be quite standoffish. There needs to be more information for the tourist or non-Hindu visiting. Beware the beggars and at the entrance who will not take no for an answer. Good for a quick visit but can be easily skipped in favour of nicer attractions in the Jaffna peninsula. .
This old grand Kovil was undergoing even more repairs on the day we visited. We (my wife and parents) were admiring the grandeur of the Kovil, its construction and the Vel cart.

We went for the 5pm puja which was amazing.  I've been to Hindu temples in other places but the temples and prayers were really incredible.  The people there were also very keen to explain what was happening and including us in the ceremony.

The kovil has a wonderful cloistered courtyard on one side - and the architectural proportions are reminiscent of similar religious buildings in Europe. The ornament, colour and general organisation of course is typically South Indian.

This Hindu Temple or Kovil is one of the largest in Jaffna Town. It is very impressive from outside but due to the timings to visit this place we missed out on this opportunity as we arrived there late. many visitors do visit this place to make ceremonial offerings to the Gods.

This is one of the largest Hindu temples in Sri Lanka which is situated in Jaffna Peninsula in the previously war-torn Northern Province. Those who are interested in taking a look at the culture, this is a good place to visit. There are ceremonious offerings which are done on particular times of the day and they are called "poojas". I went for the one that was at ten o'clock in the morning. Men are not allowed to go into this temple without removing their shirts. It is considered a sign of disrespect if men walk into the "Kovil" (Temple) wearing the shirt. Before entering this shrine people are expected to remove their footwear and wash their feet. There are small square shaped incense lumps for sale outside the shrine. Most of the people who go in buy these so that they can burn these incense lumps inside the kovil. Some people also buy coconuts and smash them outside the temple. This is a symbolic way of expecting the interior of your soul to be pure and clear like the insides of the coconut. The tamil people believe that it is best to have your coconut smashed into tiny pieces because it is representative of the vanishing of all evil in a person. Inside the temple there are "poosaries" (the religious leaders). Anyone from the Tamil community cannot become a poosary. The caste system is quite prevalent amongst the Tamil community up to date and the poosaries are only selected from the highest class of Brahmis. There are small tickets to purchase and it costs Rs. 1.00 and once you hand this over to the poosary and tell your name and starsign he blesses you.
The building is very impressive from the outside. Sadly in the three days I was there I never saw the interior open. No one could tell me when it might be open.
I liked this temple for its serene atmosphere and peaceful surroundings- it was a very nice place- I went with my grandparents, father and brother.

This Kovil was an oasis of calm and tranquility for me on a difficult return to the Jaffna area after 40 years and I left feeling more at peace with my experiences than when I entered. Uninterrupted, I could wander around, taking in the acts of devotions and worship people were making around me and enjoy the beautiful murals and other works of art that adorned the walls, ceilings and floors gaining an appreciation of the demonstration of Hinduism in this area. It was interesting to see not only those of the Hindu faith worshipping but also devout Buddhists and Catholics as well. Of course, shoes must be removed at the gate. I found that although I danced ungraciously across the hot ground on the way in, leaving was easier on the feet. Men must remove their shirts and any other upper body clothing as well.

I've heard a lot about this temple from my mother and I just had to agree with her on the magnificance of this temple. It's a shame we weren't there during the festival in August. But nonetheless a must go place while in Jaffna.

The big Temple of North SL worships their form of Skanda, son of Shiva, god of War -- called Murugan in these parts.  Dudes take off your shirts, ladies keep em on.  Even during the August holy month, the temple isn't that crowded and its a great place to sit and enjoy.  Many many ice cream stands near by....
Best temple to visit in Srilnaka. Beautiful and good place to pray. Go early in the morning if you want to be less crowded

No entrance fee, men are required to remove shirts, women must have legs and shoulders covered, ceremony at  5pm probably best time to get there Architecture is brilliant.  It is absolutely wonderful,lot to see inside. This is a 'must 'to see if you are in Jaffna. Don't miss it. No pictures inside the Kovil .Respect the local culture by the dress code
Worth to stop by here and have a look inside! Nice colours and things to see, too bad you can't take any photos.

Best times to visit are during the evening pujas (on the hour from 4 to 6 pm). The orange colour is also very photogenic against the blue sky at this time of day.  NB No photography allowed inside so you can just soak up the atmosphere of devotees rushing around following the priests and their fires, drums beating, and horns.
